awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Red lines and Negotiables: How Exposure to Wartime Violence Influences Support for Peace Settlements
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will study how exposure to wartime conditions influences public support for different possible peace settlements. Does exposure to violence lead citizens to take a hardline approach to any peace settlements? Or does it make them more open to peace settlements in order to end the violence? To answer these questions, the project will conduct a series of surveys and survey experiments looking at which types of peace deals are considered acceptable, and conversely which terms of terms peace are unacceptable. Finding credible estimates of different potential terms of peace settlements that publics would accept during wartime is a crucial national security question that can influence the policies of national leaders on questions of wartime negotiations and war termination. 

 
What kind of peace settlements would a public living through the violence of a foreign invasion be willing to accept? How does exposure to violence and displacement influence these attitudes? These are crucial questions to understanding war termination. In this project researchers develop a novel theory of how exposure to wartime violence leads people to harden resolve on certain issues by turning negotiable terms of settlement into “red lines,” while being increasingly flexible on other terms of settlement. Using a survey experimental approach, along with novel measurements of self-reported and observational exposure to violence paired with administrative data, this project will test hypotheses when and why citizens engage in both deontological (red lines) and consequentialist (negotiables) reasoning during wartime when considering different possible peace plans. The results of this project will make innovative and significant contributions to scholarship on questions relating to the causes of public opinion, wartime negotiations, and the domestic sources of war termination.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
How does exposure to violence during war influence attitudes and opinions? Our project examined this crucial question amidst one of the most severe conflicts in Europe since World War II—the Russian Invasion of Ukraine in 2022 and the subsequent Russo-Ukrainian War. We conducted a series of public opinion surveys in July 2022 and then again in May 2023.

 

Measuring public opinion during war poses serious challenges to researchers and policymakers. Previous studies that examine the impact of exposure to violence on political attitudes often occur after the conflict has ended. This can introduce various biases in the findings. For instance, the composition of the population may change due to population movements or casualties, leading to survivorship bias. Additionally, respondents may not accurately recall past events, causing recall bias. Even surveys conducted during the conflict can be influenced by how respondents are recruited (online, face-to-face, or via telephone), potentially biasing the results by selecting individuals with varying levels of exposure to the conflict (sampling bias).

 

Our project adopted an innovative approach to tackle these challenges. In order to examine the impact of violence exposure on attitudes during the Ukrainian conflict, we conducted a series of surveys and survey experiments. To ensure comprehensive coverage and address the limitations of each contact mode, we employed a combination of mobile phone and online survey sampling. In July 2022, we surveyed over 3,000 Ukrainians via mobile phones.  We surveyed more than 3,000 Ukrainians in July 2022 via mobile phones. The advantage of surveying Ukrainians via mobile phones is that in Ukraine an extremely high percentage of Ukrainians own mobile phones. Yet surveying Ukrainians via mobile phones also has its drawbacks, especially during conflict. Intermittent service interruption and displacement make it likely that we would miss certain populations. Online panels in Ukraine skew younger, more educated, and more urban—precisely the populations that are likely to be displaced and become refugees. So we also surveyed more than 1,700 Ukrainians in July 2022 via an online panel. The online panel survey also allowed us to run a longitudinal, panel study to track how shifts in exposure to violence change attitudes towards peace settlement. Finally, we currently have a mobilephone 2,000-person survey in the field (May-June 2023) that measures long-term exposure to violence during the war. 

 

Across all our surveys we asked the same questions about willingness to support different hypothetical peace settlements with Russia. We also asked questions about respondents’ beliefs in conspiracy theories popular during the war. Finally,  we also included multiple questions about exposure to violence. Our preliminary findings suggest that exposure to violence in Ukraine is high. Contrary to prevailing arguments, exposure to violence does not harden attitudes towards peace. On the contrary, Ukrainians who have experienced more violence tend to be more open to negotiations with Russia and potential peace agreements. Furthermore, our research reveals the widespread prevalence of belief in wartime conspiracy theories.

 

Based on the data we have collected, we have planned to write three papers. The first paper will focus on the relationship between exposure to violence and support for peace. The second paper will delve into the subject of support for wartime conspiracy theories. Lastly, we intend to write a methods paper that outlines an accurate approach to measuring public opinion during times of war. Currently, we have completed two rough drafts and have presented one of the papers at the International Studies Association conference in 2023. We are eagerly awaiting the opportunity to update the papers with the results from our recent survey data conducted in May-June 2023.
